# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import plotly.express as px
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.graph_objects as go
sns.set_style("darkgrid", {"grid.color": ".6", "grid.linestyle": ":"})

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

source.4c899d5a: data['7.How long does it take you to download a song of 4 minutes?'].value_counts()
source.35bcf3c3:
data['7.How long does it take you to download a song of 4 minutes?'] = data['7.How long does it take you to download a song of 4 minutes?'].map(
{'Less than 1 min':'< 1 min', '1 min to 2 mins':'1-2 mins', '5 mins to 10 mins':'5-10 mins', '2 mins to 5 mins': '2-5 mins'})
source.1fde4756:
down_index = data['7.How long does it take you to download a song of 4 minutes?'].value_counts().index.to_list()
down_count = data['7.How long does it take you to download a song of 4 minutes?'].value_counts().to_list()
source.01608203:
fig = go.Figure([go.Bar(x=down_index, y=down_count,width=0.5,)])
fig.update_layout(title_text='Time taken to dowload a song of 4 min')
fig.show()
source.d078bd03: data['8.How much data do you use each month?'].value_counts()
source.3783e590:
data['8.How much data do you use each month?'] = data['8.How much data do you use each month?'].map(
    {'1GB to 10GB': '1-10 GB', '10GB to 50GB': '10-50 GB', 'More than 50GB': '>50GB', '100MB to 1GB' : '100MB-1GB'})
source.82eadedb:
data_index = data['8.How much data do you use each month?'].value_counts().index.to_list()
data_count = data['8.How much data do you use each month?'].value_counts().to_list()
source.f99e46c9:
fig = go.Figure([go.Bar(x=data_index, y=data_count,width=0.5)])
fig.update_layout(title_text='Data uage in a Month')
fig.show()

index = data['11.Which network are you likely to recommend to a tourist who is in town for a few days?'].value_counts().index.to_list()
count = data['11.Which network are you likely to recommend to a tourist who is in town for a few days?'].value_counts().to_list()
source.56c400f3:

fig.update_layout(title_text='Network Recommendation for Tourist')
fig.show()
source.dee0929c:
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Pie(labels=data['12.Which network do you use more often?'].value_counts().index.to_list(), 
                             values=data['12.Which network do you use more often?'].value_counts().to_list(), hole=.3)])
fig.update_layout(title_text='Most used Network')
fig.show()
source.4ba11eed:
fig = go.Figure([go.Bar(x=data['19.Do you think the telecommunications market in India is tilting towards a monopoly?'].value_counts().index.to_list(), 
                        y=data['19.Do you think the telecommunications market in India is tilting towards a monopoly?'].value_counts().to_list(),width=0.4)])
fig.update_layout(title_text='Do you think the telecommunications market in India is tilting towards a monopoly?')
fig.show()
